sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: Qalculate! is not your regular software replication of the cheapest available calculator. Qalculate! aims to make full use of the superior interface, power and flexibility of modern computers.

The center of attention in Qalculate! is the expression entry, Instead of entering each number in an mathematical expression separately, you can directly input the whole expression and later modify it. Just enter your expression as you would write it on a paper, press Enter and voila!
The interpretation of expressions is flexible, fault tolerant and if you nevertheless do something wrong Qalculate! will tell you so.

In addition to numbers and arithmetic operators (+,-,*,/) an expression may contain any combination of variables, units, and functions. These are immediately accessible from the interface - the menus in the upper right corner, the managers, and calculator buttons.
Qalculate! also has some special tools to increase your efficiency, including a fast number base conversion dialog and a simple plotting interface.

Although use of Qalculate! for simple calculations should be natural and self-explanatory, reading the rest of the manual can help you maximize your productivity and discover some maybe unexpected features. More advanced users should read on and discover a large number of customization options and the ability to create and modify your own variables, functions and units directly from the user interface.

sect2.title: The Main Window
sect2.para: The expression entry is the most important part of the Qalculate! user interface. The normal calculation procedure in Qalculate! is to type in a mathematical expression (ex. 1+1) and press Enter (or click Execute). The result (2) is then displayed below the expression entry in the result display.
There is some convenient functions that may not be obvious.

After execution of an expression, the whole expression will be marked. This normally means that if you enter something new the old expression will be replaced. If you, however, enter an operator first you will instead continue on your old expression. The entered operator applies to the whole expression, which is put in parenthesis. This works on all marked ranges, meaning that you can conveniently get an expression put in parenthesis.

The Up and Down keys will access your previously entered expressions. Press Up with focus in the expression entry and you traverse backwards in you expression history and Down will traverse forward.
The main window

sect2.title: Main Buttons
sect2.para: In the bottom of the main window three buttons are accessible. Close on the right simply closes/exits Qalculate!, Execute executes the calculation of entered expression (same as Enter), while More >> (<< Less) button shows/hides calculator buttons and calculation history.
Right of the expression entry and the result display are two small buttons with arrows. These open the expression menu and the result menu respectively.

sect2.title: Calculator Buttons
sect2.para:
In the buttons tab you have access to a fairly small set of traditional calculator buttons, which works as expected. The Convert button opens the convert to unit dialog, while the buttons on the top right side opens functions, variables and units manage dialogs respectively.
Calculator Buttons

sect2.title: Calculation History
sect2.para:
In the history tab you have access to your full calculation history (20 rows are reloaded on restart). Previous expressions and results, as well as errors and warnings, are displayed in plain text and can be marked and copied (from the right button context menu or with CtrlC) to the expression entry or elsewhere.
Calculation History

sect2.title: The Convert Number Bases Dialog
sect2.para:
The number bases dialog, accessible from the Expression Menu or CtrlB, is a fast and convenient tool for conversion between binary, octal, decimal and hexadecimal numbers. This dialog contains entries for each of the number bases. When you type in numbers in any of entries, the others are automatically updated to display the current number in their format. The numbers, or expressions, entered follow the same rules as expressions in the main expression entry.
Convert Number Bases Dialog

sect2.title: Objects

listitem.para: These are the regular numbers composed the digits 0-9 and the decimal point - a dot or comma depending on the language. Seperators (ex. 1,000.00), usually comma or dot whichever is not the decimal point, are not allowed. This includes integers, real numbers, and complex numbers. Spaces between digits are ignored (5 5 = 55). The imaginary part of complex numbers are written with a regular followed by the special variable i, which represents the square root of -1 (ex. 2 + 3i).
Vectors and matrices are either generated by the vector or matrix functions, or stored in a variable. Syntax in the form of [[1, 2], [3, 4]] is not yet supported.
Prefixes must be put immediately before the unit to be interpreted as prefixes - 5 mm = 0.005 m, but 5 m m = 5m^2. More information in .
Unknown variables are text strings without any associated value.

This category represent a number of different argument types, such regular text, dates and file names. They can, but do not need to be put in quotes except when containing the argument separator (, or ;).

sect2.para: To avoid confusion, functions, units, variables and unknown variables can independently be disabled.
Unknown letters are each treated separately as unknown variables (xy=x*y). To enter unknown variables consisting of more than one letter, you must put them in quotes (ex. "xy" or 'xy').

If you do not remember all needed variables, units and functions, all is accessible in the menus in the function, variable and unit managers. Function accessed this way has some extra conveniences. If the function has at least one argument, a dialog will pop up where you can enter arguments and see descriptions of arguments and the functions.
For more information about variables, functions and units, see , and .

sect2.title: Operators
sect2.para:
The following operators are defined in Qalculate! and may be used in expressions.
Addition +: Ex. 1 + 1 returns 2.
Subtraction -: Ex. 1 - 1 returns 0.
Division /: Ex. 2 / 2 returns 1.
Multiplication *: Ex. 2 * 2 returns 4.
Exponent ^: Can also be typed as **. Ex. 2^3 returns 8.
10^x E: Ex. 1E3 returns 1000.
Parenthesis ( and ): Ex. 5 * (1 + 1) returns 10.
Less than <: Returns 1 for true, if the left value is is less than the right, and 0 for false. Ex. 1<2 returns 1.
Greater than >: Returns 1 for true, if the left value is greater than the right, and 0 for false. Ex. 1>2 returns 0.
Less than or equal <=: Returns 1 for true, if the left value is is less than or equal the right, and 0 for false. Ex. 1<=2 returns 1.
Greater than or equal >=: Returns 1 for true, if the left value is is greater than or equal the right, and 0 for false. Ex. 1>=2 returns 0.
Equals =: Returns 1 for true, if the left value equals the right, and 0 for false. Ex. 1=2 returns 0.
Not equals !=: Returns 1 for true, if the left value not equals the right, and 0 for false. Ex. 1!=2 returns 1.
Logical NOT !: Returns 1 for true, if left value on the right is false, and 0 for false. Ex. !(1>2) returns 1.
Logical OR |: Returns 1 for true, if the right or left value is true, and 0 for false. Ex. 1>2 | 2>1 returns 1.
Logical AND &: Returns 1 for true, if the right and left value is true, and 0 for false. Ex. 1>2 & 2>1 returns 0.
In addition to these operators there are a couple of shortcuts for certain functions, such as 5! equals factorial(5).

The multiplication sign can generally be left out. This is not true for numbers (5 5 = 55). Expressions can generally be written with or without spaces with the same result (2xsin(2) = 2 x sin(2) = 2*x*sin(2)), but be careful. The vast number of functions and units means that without separating spaces you might not get what you expect. Also, unit prefixes must be put immediately before the unit to be interpreted as prefixes. 5 mm = 0.005 m, but 5 m m = 5m^2.

Usually the you type in mathematical expressions as normally expected. Standard operator precedence apply. Expressions are evaluated according to the following priorities:
Functions (ex. sqrt(2))
Short multiplication in front of variables, units, functions, parenthesis etc. (ex. 5(2+3)). Note that this implies that 2/5 cm equals 2/(5 cm) and not (2/5) cm
Exponents (x^y)
Multiplication and division (*, /)
Addition and subtraction (+, -)
Comparison (>, <, =, >=, <=)
AND (&)
OR (|)

sect1.title: Result Presentation
sect1.para:
Qalculate! provides a flexible result display. There are several ways, accessible from the result menu, in which you can customize the display of the result. These are summarized below:
Number bases. You can select with which base numbers will be displayed. Only decimal numbers support decimals and therefore the other bases are displayed as fractions if necessary (ex. 0.01 = 0x1/0x64).
Numerical display.
Fractional mode. This controls if numbers will be displayed in fractional or decimal mode. Decimal mode displays numbers as usually expected (6/4 = 1.5), combined display a whole number and a fraction (6/4 = 1 1/2) and fractional only displays only as fraction (6/4 = 3/2).
Indicate infinite series (under numerical display in menu). If this option is on, Qalculate! will not round infinitely repeating digit sequences if discovered. Instead ... will be displayed after the maximal number of decimals and the result indicated as exact (compare 2/3 = 0.666667 with 2/3 = 0.666666...).
Exact mode. This mode does actually not only affect the display but also the calculation. When exact mode is on, the calculation will not go further than what can be calculated exactly (ex. sqrt(2+3) = sqrt(5)).
Precision
Decimals. In the decimals dialog you can control how many decimals will be displayed. You can control minimal numbers of decimal (will fill out with zeros) and maximal numbers of decimals (will round numbers).
In front of the result an equals or approximately equals sign is shown. This shows if Qalculate! was able to calculate/display the result exactly with the current mode.

sect1.title: Variables
sect1.para: Variables are used to conveniently store a fixed value/result under a name. Variables may store everything that a result may contain, including numbers, units, unknown variables, unsolved expressions and functions etc.

Some common constants such as pi and e that cannot be exactly be represented by a real number are special variables. They are not fixed but are recalculated each time precision changes, thereby not compromising the arbitrary precision of Qalculate!.
Another special and very useful variable is the ans variable, which always contains the last calculated result.

sect2.title: Variable creation/editing
sect2.para:
The simples way of creating a variable is to store the current result. You can do this by pressing the STO button or selecting Result MenuStore Result. You then type a name for the variable in the dialog that pops up. You may also optionally enter a category and descriptive name for the variable to keep your variables well organized.
Store Result

sect1.title: Functions
sect1.para:
Functions is normally entered in an expression by entering the name followed by arguments, separated by commas (or semicolons in languages with comma as decimal point), in parenthesis, thus following the syntax name(arg1, arg2, ...).
Insert function dialog

Although it can lower readability of the expression it is perfectly legal to skip the parenthesis and put the arguments after a space and ended with space (no spaces then allowed in argument listing). This is most useful in short expressions with single argument functions (ex. sqrt 5).

The possible argument types are:
Free - anything
Number - a number
Integer - a whole number
Text - a free text string
Date - a date in local or standard format (Year-Month-Day, recommended)
Vector
Matrix
Boolean - 0 for false, 1 for true
Object - the name of a variable, function or unit
Variable - the name of a variable
Function - the name of a function
Unit - the name of a unit
File - the path to a file
Angle - an angle used in trigonometric functions, meaning a number and an angle unit. If no angle unit is included the default is used.
Giac - as free. Used in giac connected functions.
The argument can be restricted by further conditions. For example that a number must be positive.

sect2.title: Available Functions
sect2.para: Here the main function categories and and their vital functions will be described to give you an overview over available functions. The right place for information about separate functions is however in the function manager.

sect2.title: Function creation/editing
sect2.para: Functions are a bit more complex than variables, but can nevertheless be relatively easy the create. Select create new function in the menu or in the function manager and the function edit dialog pops up. First enter a name, used to reference the function in an expression. If you enter an expression a bit further down, than you will already have a working function. A bit more does however need to be said about the function expression.

The expression of the function is basically a regular expression with placeholders for arguments. These placeholders consists of a backslash and a letter -- x, y, z for the 1st, 2nd and 3rd argument and a to u for argument 4 to 24. These placeholders are replaced by entered arguments when the function is calculated. They naturally also decides the number of argument that the function requires. For example the function for triangle area (base * height / 2) has the name triangle and the expression (\x*\y)/2 which gives that triangle(2, 3) equals (2*3) / 2 and gives 3 as result. An argument can be used more than one time and they need not be in order in the expression.
The function edit dialog

Additionally optional arguments can be put in the expression with upper-case letters (X, Y, Z, ...) instead lower-case letters (x, y, z, ...). The default value can be put in brackets after the letter (ex. \X{2}). The default value may be omitted and is then zero. All additional arguments after an optional argument must also be optional. There are also two special arguments represented by \v and \w. These represents an arbitrary number of arguments at the end, which are put in a vector. The difference is \w treats each argument one vector component, while \v extracts all components from all arguments that are matrices or vectors.

Below the expression you can optionally enter an condition that must be true (>0) for the function to be calculated. This follows the same conventions as the function expressions. For example if the second argument must be higher than the first you may enter \y > \x as condition.
Further, name, type and condition for each argument can be specified.

The keep functions well organized you can enter a category, a descriptive name and a description. You can also choose to hide a function from the menus with the corresponding check box, which can be useful for sub functions.

caution.para: Note that some functions are hard-coded and cannot be changed by the user.

sect2.title: Conversion
sect2.para: You can convert an expression to a specific unit directly in the expression entry with the to operator which converts an expression to a specified unit (ex. 5 feet + 2 inches to cm converts the result of 5 feet + 2 inches to centimeters and displays it). Note that the command to is localized, meaning that if you have Qalculate! with Swedish translation, then you should use till instead. Unit expression may only contain units, prefixes, exponents, multiplication and division. Other elements are ignored.

You can also use the unit conversion dialog, accessible from the Convert button, Result MenuConvert to unitEnter custom unit, or CtrlT. You enter your unit in the dialog that pops up and the displayed result is then converted.
Unit Conversion Dialog
The final way to convert to another unit is to use the predefined units in the Convert to unit menu or press Convert result in the unit manager.
Note that when you convert to a single unit every occurrence of the unit is replaced (5 km/h to s = 1.39 m/s), while a unit expression with multiple units converts the whole expression.

sect2.title: Unit creation/editing
sect2.para: There are three different unit classes in Qalculate! -- base, alias and composite units. Base units is the units defined as the basis for other units. Meters and seconds are typical base units. Alias units is defined in relation to another unit, for example hour are defined as an alias unit that equals 60 minutes which in turn is defined in relation to seconds. Finally, composite units are defined by a unit expression with multiple unit. Composite units often has an alias unit associated with them, as they do not have a reference name on their own. For example, a joule is defined as a alias defined in in relation to the a composite unit defined as Newton * meter.

Select create new unit in the menu or in the unit manager and the unit edit dialog pops up.
The unit edit dialog
First you need to select the unit class. Depending on the unit class different elements in the dialog will be enabled. For all units, category and descriptive name can be specified to keep them well organized. You can also choose to hide a unit from the menus with the corresponding check box, which can be useful for some composite units.

Base and alias units may have three different name forms defined for use in expressions -- short (ex. m), singular (meter) and plural (meters). At least the short name must be specified. Composite units only have an (mandatory) internal name, used to reference the unit in definitions of other units.

For base units the name is all that is needed. For alias units, on the other hand, a base unit, exponent and relation is necessary. For more complex relations a reversed relation can also be specified for conversion back from the base unit. The base unit must not necessarily be of the base unit class and it is recommended that an alias unit is defined in relation to the closest unit (ex. 1ft = 3 hands, 1 hand = 4 in, and 1 in = 0.0254 m). The relation is usually just a number that tells how much of the base unit is needed to get the alias unit (alias unit = base unit * relation). More complex can specify the relation as an full-blown expression where \x is relaced by the number of the base unit and \y is the exponent. For example Degrees Celcius has the relation \x + 273.15 and the reversed relation \x - 273.15 to the base unit Kelvin. For simple relations the reversion is automatic and ought not be defined separately, With the check box below relation in the dialog you can specify if the relation is exact or approximate. The exponent defines the exponential relation to the base unit, so that the alias unit equals the base unit raised to the exponent. For simple unit relations this gives: alias unit = relation * base unit^exponent.
Composite unit must specify a unit expression with multiple units as base in the base unit field. This expression may only contain units, prefixes, exponents, multiplication and division (ex. km/h).

caution.para: Note that even though Qalculate! does all the calculations before handing over the data to gnuplot, the resulting data must only consist of pure numbers as gnuplot knows nothing about the functions, variables, units, etc. of Qalculate!.
